A very heavy and anchored deer stand was blown over and damaged 1/2 mile north of the house.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in the Oakwood Estates mobile home park along Spirit Lake Road south of County Road 540.  Approximately twelve mobile homes sustained minor to moderate roof, lanai and siding damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The weak tornado caused little damage.  It ripped up a section of fencing and dropped it 25 ft from its original location and some other debris was blown around.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: weak tornado damaged some trailers in a trailer  park. Minor damage to a few trailers.

The thunderstorm that produced the tornado formed along a squall line moving southeast across the area.  Damage path consisted of numerous snapped and fallen trees.  Twelve mobile homes were severely damaged from fallen trees and one mobile home was pushed off its foundation.  Roofs were removed from two frame homes.
Damage path consisted of snapped tree limbs, trees pushed over, and trees topped.  No structures were in the damage path.
A weak tornado touched down in Garibaldi and moved a mobile home 2 feet in the air and dropped it about 3 feet off of it's foundation.
A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural Polk county. A  house was slightly damaged by a falling tree.
A weak tornado near Yacolt knocked down 3 trees and a telephone pole.
A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural Polk County. Some farms sustained minor crop damage.
A tornado briefly touched down in the Eagle Crest Resort along Cline Falls Highway north of Bend.  Some juniper trees were blown down,  fences rolled up,  and about 10 acres of hay were ripped up.

Tornado skipped through a mobile home park along County Road 9 and Market Street.  Two mobile homes destroyed with more than a dozen damaged.  Large power poles and trees toppled.  Winds overturned small airplane off County Road 81 near Harmon School.  A large tree blown onto a house on County Road 75.  Residence destroyed on Alabama Highway 84 West in Wicksburg.

Tornado touchdown in Currytown community trailer park along Dale County Road 49, Dean Road, and Alabama 134 between Pinckard and Midland City. Three mobile homes were destroyed and four were heavily damaged.  16-18 residences sustained structural damage.  Six barns were leveled and four were damaged.  Numerous large trees and power poles down.
Destroyed 2 houses
A tornado destroyed two mobile homes and damaged a house. The tornado was sighted by Sheriffs Office personnel when it touched down.
109 houses/businesses sustained damage.  This tornado was mostly F0 with some F1 damage.
watersout crossed road near walker island.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summary of events of the afternoon and evening of August 17, 1997:Severe thunderstorms moved along and south of the Red River, producing large hail, damaging thunderstorm winds, and two tornadoes in western parts of north Texas.  The tornadoes were observed south of Windthorst in Archer County.  No damage was reported and both were rated at F0.  The largest hail was reported near Harrold in Wilbarger County, where hail reached the size of golf balls.  The most significant wind damage occurred in Clay County, where severe thunderstorm winds caused major damage to a group of houses and barns and then derailed a freight train near Jolly.  Significant wind damage was also reported in the Henrietta area of Clay County and  in Iowa park in Wichita County.See preceding individual Storm Data entries for further details and additional reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down in an open field about 1/2 mile west of Highway 16.  It was on the ground for about 3 minutes and did no reported damage.
Tornado destroyed 1 mobile home and damaged 4 others.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An F0 (on the Fujita Scale) tornado briefly touched down on Fairview Drive within West Goshen Township in Chester County at 1215 p.m. EST.  Its path length was less than one-tenth of a mile and its path width was about 50 yards.  Nevertheless, the tornado uprooted several trees on the block and split several other tree trunks.  It also turned a mint condition antique car on its side and the shed it was stored in was lifted and tossed about 30 feet.  The snow thrower, riding lawn mower and other equipment within the shed littered the back yard.  No injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the Forester Exit of Interstate 8 and skipped along to the northwest for approximately 1.5 miles. In its path, 16 power poles were destroyed, with some having been snapped or pulled from the ground, large trees were knocked down, outhouses were blown down, and tarps were lifted from hay stacks.
A tornado briefly touched down and toppled trees and power lines near U.S. Highway 41 and Pearl Avenue.
A tornado briefly touched down and toppled trees and power lines near 59th Street and Cortez Blvd. before it lifted and dissipated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced a tornado as it moved into St. Tammany Parish. The tornado was first observed by the State Police on Interstate Highway 12 west of  Covington. From data collected on a ground, damage survey by the National Weather Service, the tornado moved on a path slightly north of due east. The tornado moved across the downtown area of Covington and continued east for nearly 2 miles before lifting off the ground.  Most of the damage along path indicated F1 damage, however, several areas near downtown Covington were classified as F2 damage. Parish officials reported 43 injuries were reported with tornado, though most were relatively minor. Six persons required and overnight stay in a hospital, including three pregnant women. Most of the damage to homes was due to large pine trees which had been toppled onto houses. In downtown Covington, a few large buildings lost roofs, had windows blown out, or suffered substantial damage. A large parish building suffered $500,000 damage. Media reports indicated cleanup would cost several million dollars. Just east of the downtown area, several cars were lifted and moved tens of feet by the tornado, and an empty tractor-trailer truck rig was blown over. Nearly 50 cars in a parking lot had their windows blown out by debris or by rapid pressure drop. The same parent thunderstorm spawned another tornado just south of Talisheek damaging a barn and a house. The damage path length at Talisheek was estimated.   American Red Cross reports indicated 69 single family homes were destroyed or had major damage in St. Tammany Parish.  Four public buildings were also heavily damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down over Cascade Head around 830 AM.

A tornado touched down along State Road 37 near State Road 640 and uprooted or snapped, half-way up, 50 to 60 pine trees, destroyed a shed and caused structural damage to a home in rural western Polk county before it lifted and dissipated.
Another tornado was reported near Macleay at 1105 am. No damages reported.
A resident of Pacific City reported seeing a funnel clouod over the ocean touch down briefly over the ocean and again inland. No damages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms developed in a moist unstable airmass ahead of a slow moving cold front.  As the lines moved slowly north, a thunderstorm produced a weak (F1)  short-lived (about 30 seconds)  tornado in West Milford township.The tornado formed in the Wonder Lake area just east of Germantown Road (off Route 23 North) and moved north.  It  was confirmed by National Weather Service Meteorologists.High winds downed about 150 trees, two of which fell through a house and the Wonder Lake Clubhouse.  At least 4 trees fell on and damaged cars.  High winds also downed numerous power lines.Heavy rain also caused flooding of streets and poor drainage areas.  Here are selected rainfall amounts for Western Passaic County:Charlotteburg      - 4.83 inchesGreenwood Lake - 4.34 inchesWest Milford       - 4.18 inches.

Sight survey by a NWS employee showed a severe thunderstorm moved across extreme northern Webster county into Marion and Schley counties. Another storm moved into Webster county further south. These two storms may have merged together. The storm continued across Schley county and caused some damage in Macon county before weakening. There were no actual tornado sightings, but there was a suggestion of rotation/circulation by occurrences of large trees lying at angles to each other. There was only one report of a funnel, but roaring, "freight train" sounds were heard. Radar also indicated a definite rotation as well. Most of the damage may have been due to downburst winds, but there were strong indications of intermittent touchdowns of an F1 tornado. Luckily there were no injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West of Draneville, nearly 50 trees were knocked down and several grain silos and out-buildings were damaged. A church just southeast of Draneville on highway 30 was destroyed. Its roof was blown into a nearby orchard, where 116 pecan trees were also destroyed. The roof of a youth center was lifted off. A gas station/grocery store sustained minor damage.
A  tornado caused minor damage to fences windows and trees in a rural subdivision near Turner.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms developed across Colfax County prior to the passage of a strong cold front. Storms developed repeatedly over south central areas of the county between Springer and Cimarron and sped northeast mainly across open range. A number of small and short lived tornadoes were recorded during late afternoon. Storms continued to develop into the early and mid-evening with straightline wind and hail damage reported in Raton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado was observed on the Tooth of Time ridge southwest of Cimarron.
Ten homes destroyed, four with major damage, and 17 sustained minor damage. A four mile line of standing pine timber was completely destroyed.
A weak F1 tornado moving northeast over Lake Tohopekaliga touched down in the Kissimmee Park community southwest of St. Cloud. The tornado destroyed 4 mobile homes and damaged 10 other structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An F1 tornado touched down in northern sections of the city of Lafayette, near Interstate 10, between Poplar Street and Hebert Road. Three permanent homes were destoyed, 12 had major damage, and another 22 had minor damage. There were also two mobile homes that were destroyed, four with major damage, and eight with minor damage. The Lafayette Utilities System power plant received the most damage, where over 3.0 million dollars worth of damages occurred when two water coolers were destroyed. This tornado first touched down in a mobile home park, then hit the power plant, followed by a residential area. Fortunately, only one injury occurred. A woman in one of the mobile homes destroyed was treated at a local hospital for a concussion.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down at the Temple Heights Christian School football field near North 46th Street and Regnas Boulevard and lifted along Riverhills road in Tampa.  The tornado snapped several large trees along it's narrow path before it lifted and dissipated.
A tornado touched down and severely damaged a pool cage, barn roof and downed several oak trees near State Road 64 and Upper Manatee River Road.
A brief tornado touched down one eighth of a mile north of New Pass on Longboat Key with no apparent damage.
Large trees and power lines were blown down.

The thunderstorm that produced the tornado formed along a squall line moving across the region.  Damage consisted primarily of numerous snapped and fallen trees or trees that were topped.  One older frame home was de-roofed.

Tornado damaged 5 homes, with a large porch on one home and a garage/breezeway on another home completely destroyed. Damage to 2 other homes primarily incidental, and caused by flying debris. The fifth home sustained siding and substantial roof damage. Several boats were damaged/overturned at local marina. One row boat near initial damage area lifted up and tossed 300-400 yards from its tied-down position. Several other items were thrown distances of several hundred yards. Two cars were damaged, one severely. Several trees were severely damaged, one tree was uprooted by an airborne boat. There were no injuries or fatalities.
Off-duty NWS employee reported the touchdown of a weak tornado.

Tornado touchdown one mile east of Geneva at the intersection of County Roads 4 and 6 damaging 6 to 10 residences. 10 to 15 homes and trailers damaged on J.P. Jones Road near Oak Grove.  Numerous trees and power lines down.  Considerable damage to Christmas decorations at Fowler Park in Geneva.

OES chased a funnel cloud from just southeast of Alpine, southeastward across extreme eastern Howard County into Hempstead County.  The funnel lowered throughout the chase until it touched down and was classified as a tornado 5.5 miles south of Nashville, AR.  Damage initially consisted of broken and felled trees.  The tornado then moved over cleared pastureland and intensified on CR318 between Hwy 4 and CR 44; totally destroying several chicken coups...leaving the chickens untouched...felling a tree onto a car, and slightly damaging a house.  The tornado then began to weaken and rapidly dissipated.  Skywarn spotters living in the area, the Hempstead County Judge and OES were eyewitnesses to the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A  F0 (Fujita Scale) touched down briefly in Middletown Township and Highlands Borough before it went into Sandy Hook Bay and dissipated.   The path length was about 1.2 miles and the path width about 75 yards. The tornado damaged several cars and homes, and uprooted and/or snapped numerous trees, but no injuries were reported.  The tornado touched down in northeastern Middletown Township near Pape Drive and Navasink Avenue.   It moved northeast and uprooted a tree on Williams Street that crushed three parked cars.  Another car was burned when it came in contact with downed wires on Buttermilk Valley Road.  A tree also crushed an awning in the Shadow Lane Mobile Home Park.  In Highlands Borough,  a shed was blown off its foundation and carried by the tornado between two houses.  Other structural damage was mainly confined to broken windows, torn shingles and gutters.  Maximum wind speeds were estimated at the high end of the F0 scale at about 70 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four F1 tornado touchdowns.  Numerous 12-24" diameter trees uprooted on Gadsden County Road 159.  Considerable debris on Florida Highway 27 five miles NE of Midway.  Power outages in Midway.

F1 tornado touched down on Florida Highway 22.  A bread truck was lifted 15-20 feet into the air and thrown 100 feet into wooded area (driver seriously injured).  A semitractor fuel tanker was overturned (driver sutained minor injuries).
Small F1 tornado destroyed storage sheds, mobile home and pickup truck along Florida Highway 73.  One 24" diameter tree uprooted.
Waterspout moved ashore.  Extensive roof damage to beach front hotel, sewage treatment plant, middle school and convenient store.  One minor injury sustained from flying debris.

A tornado touched down and damaged a warehouse distribution center, overturned two tractor trailers, tore down 100 feet of chain link fence and blew down several power poles along State Road 60 near County Road 676.The tornado touched down a second time and damaged several roofs of homes and downed trees and power poles at the Christina Grove subdivision near State Road 37 and County Road 540A before it lifted and dissipated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sight survey by a NWS employee showed a severe thunderstorm moved across extreme northern Webster county into Marion and Schley counties. Another storm moved into Webster county further south. These two storms may have merged together. The storm continued across Schley county and caused some damage in Macon county before weakening. There were no actual tornado sightings, but there was a suggestion of rotation/circulation by occurrences of large trees lying at angles to each other. There was only one report of a funnel, but roaring, "freight train" sounds were heard. Radar also indicated a definite rotation as well. Most of the damage may have been due to downburst winds, but there were strong indications of intermittent touchdowns of an F1 tornado. Luckily there were no injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A state of emergency was declared in Schley county where 103 people were displaced due to the storm. In Ellaville, 5 mobile homes were destroyed, 17 homes and 11 other  mobile homes sustained minor to moderate damage, and 19 vehicles were damaged or destroyed.  The EMA director reported 500 trees were downed and power outages occurred throughout the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm winds were responsible for scattered tree and power line damage. Hardest hit was Walworth county were a barn was blown off it's foundation near Sharon (Walworth Co) and another out-building damaged.  Several other homes around the county experienced expensive lightning damage due to fires.  The 911 center in Elkhorn (Walworth Co) was temporarily disabled when lightning destroyed the communications center, forcing the use of a backup system.  In addition, lightning struck and injured a woman in Elkhorn as the storms rolled through that city. Heavy rains of 3 to 4 inches caused urban street flooding on the west side of Monroe in Green county with other incidences of urban flooding reported in Racine and Kenosha counties. In the city of Racine (Racine Co), 1.14 inches fell in 30 minutes, while west of New Munster (Kenosha Co), 3.75 inches fell in 3 hours, and resulting in street flooding around New Munster to Twin Lakes (Kenosha Co).  Many cars stalled in flooded low spots in both counties. Later in the afternoon a brief tornado touched down on the roof of an east side Lake Mills (Jefferson Cc) factory.  About 61000 square feet of the 10 acre roof was damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported and video taped by Arthur Beatty, a storm spotter for Nacogdoches, TX.  His position was on a bluff just north of Hwy 7 and west of Nacogdoches looking to the southwest as the tornado moved northeast.  This position provided good back lighting making spotting easy.  Damage along the track consisted of shallow rooted trees blown over in a convergent pattern, broken limbs, and damaged or blown over signs.  No injuries or monetary damages of significance were noted.  The tornado developed from a rotating wall cloud which lowered to the ground throughout its entire life span.
F0 tornado reported in northwest Baker County.  Several 12-24" diameter pines down along Georgia Highway 216 near Milford.

F0 tornado touchdown just southwest of Albany near Walker.  Roof damage and scattered debris along 1600 block of Oakridge Road.  Minor structural damage to a warehouse and church.  Numerous trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms developed across Colfax County prior to the passage of a strong cold front. Storms developed repeatedly over south central areas of the county between Springer and Cimarron and sped northeast mainly across open range. A number of small and short lived tornadoes were recorded during late afternoon. Storms continued to develop into the early and mid-evening with straightline wind and hail damage reported in Raton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado was observed near Maxwell.
Tree damage.

A severe thunderstorm produced a tornado that produced substantial damage in a residential area east-northeast of Latrobe along the foothills of the Chestnut Ridge.  The tornado first touched down 1 mile west of Derry.  The tornado completely destroyed a large tier of metal stadium bleachers at a high school football field and wrapped them against a utility pole.  A nearby roof of a business was damaged and a mobile home was completely destroyed and a few mobile homes sustained damage.  The tornado then tracked through a rural area, damaging some farm buildings and downing field corn.  The tornado continued its rapid (estimated forward speed 50-60 miles per hour) northeast track and caused significant damage in a mobile home park  in Derry.  The tornado crossed Route 217 and downed trees across railroad tracks and then entered a residential area in Millwood.  One frame house in Millwood was  severely damaged and part of a room addition collapsed and trapped a resident, who was treated at the scene.  A resident of a mobile home sustained minor injuries as well. Numerous trees were uprooted and large branches and power lines were downed along the track of the storm. One home along Route 217 had a branch embedded into the house siding.  The tornado was estimated to have wind speeds of between 90 and 120 miles per hour, briefly attaining an F-2 rating on the Fujita Tornado Scale.  All tolled, 7-8 mobile homes were destroyed (3 totally decimated), 10-12 sustained major damage, 15-18 sustained minor damage. One frame house was heavily damaged and about 10 sustained minor damage.  One car was destroyed when a tree fell on it.  Parked next to the auto was another car with two occupants that were not injured.  About 10 other cars were damaged.  An open-air church in Millwood was also heavily damaged.   The tornado appeared to have dissipated as it entered the heavily wooded slopes of the Chestnut Ridge.
F1 tornado struck a chicken farm at Alabama Highway 27 and Dale County Road 67.  Six of eight chicken houses were destroyed.  Approximately 25,000 chickens were killed.
A Mohave County Deputy Sheriff sighted a tornado briefly touching down in open country near I-40.
Barn roof destroyed. Large trees and power lines were blown down.

An isolated severe thunderstorm developed in western Osage County during the afternoon of September 8th and moved south into Pawnee County. The storm produced 2 brief tornadoes in open country. The tornadoes touched down at 1545CST 5 miles north of Fairfax and at 1620CST 2 miles northwest of Ralston. No structural damage occurred with the tornadoes, and both tornadoes were rated F0 in intensity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms developed across Colfax County prior to the passage of a strong cold front. Storms developed repeatedly over south central areas of the county between Springer and Cimarron and sped northeast mainly across open range. A number of small and short lived tornadoes were recorded during late afternoon. Storms continued to develop into the early and mid-evening with straightline wind and hail damage reported in Raton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado was photographed over the T-O Ranch southeast of Raton.
Minor damage was done to a church and a house and another house had roof damage. Several trees were blown down.
Tornado skipped along and just North of SR-94. Large trees and tops of trees were destroyed.
Large trees and tops of trees were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms developed across Colfax County prior to the passage of a strong cold front. Storms developed repeatedly over south central areas of the county between Springer and Cimarron and sped northeast mainly across open range. A number of small and short lived tornadoes were recorded during late afternoon. Storms continued to develop into the early and mid-evening with straightline wind and hail damage reported in Raton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second small tornado developed on the CS Ranch east of Cimarron.

Thunderstorms in advance of a strong low pressure trough, spawned a tornado that briefly touched down off of Huntington Beach, and moved onshore, crossing Highway 1, into Huntington Harbor.  The twister ripped at least 6 boats from their moorings, damaged trees, ripped a 40-foot metal light pole out of the ground, tossed a 150 pound iron bench into a spa, and ripped a 25 foot section of roof from a home.  Damage to the roof alone was estimated at $15,000.

A tornado was observed east of Eagle City.  It remained on the ground for about 3 minutes and caused tree and fence damage for about a half mile.  Large trees along this path were uprooted and the tornado was rated F0.
touched down near 3 st/powerline rd by pompano park race track. shingles torn from roof. one truck overturned. several tres down.
Brief tornado moving southeast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado, up to 1/4 mile wide, tracked through the high country of central Mineral county.  The 3-mile long track extended from the northeast side of Fisher mountain to Copper mountain, between 10,500 and 11,500 feet above MSL.  It snapped off or uprooted tens of thousands of spruce and pine trees and destroyed a horse trailer.  Nearby eyewitnesses described a definite twisting motion to the destructive wind.

Deep southerly flow of modified tropical air produce two small spin-up tornadoes in the western Virginia piedmont  during the late afternoon.  The first touchdown occurred near Orange.  A witness at the Piedmont Research Center saw a funnel cloud briefly touch down into a field, causing a debris swirl (most likely dirt and grass).  The tornado  lifted as quickly as it touched down, near federal highway 15.  A survey team noted only a swirling effect flattened grass in the field.A stronger twister touched down about an hour later near Radiant.  The twister, witnessed by several onlookers, first moved across a farm field, causing minor damage to a building and an adjacent satellite dish before flipping an empty livestock truck.  The truck, which landed on hay bales, was undamaged.  The storm moved through a wooded area, then moved into a residential area where a dozen trees were uprooted or snapped.  Minor damage was sustained to the houses.  The twister then dissipated.  Estimated winds ranged from 70 to 80 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down in the Bear Creek Community.  Damage was mostly trees but a volunteer fire department building was heavily damaged.

The tornado first touched down on the east shore of Lake Houston and moved northeast into extreme  western Liberty County.  This tornado was mostly F0 and F1 with some F2 damage at Foley Rd and Dallas Rd where a boat house was extremely damaged.  An 18-wheeler in the same area was overturned and moved 50 feet.
Trees blown down.
Trees blown down and minor roof damage.

A tornado touched down near the intersection of Thonotasassa and Gallagher Roads and lifted near Forbes Road.  Two mobile homes were destroyed while thirteen others suffered minor damage.  One two story home suffered significant siding damage while a barn was flattened by the tornado.  Several large trees were snapped half way up the base by the tornadic wind.  Also, a doghouse was destroyed by the tornado.
A tornado destroyed garage doors, damaged the roofs of five homes, and blew down trees and power lines.
A tornado briefly touched down and uprooted a few trees, twisted a couple of stop signs and downed a couple of power lines on Caladesi Island State Park.

A tornado touched down near the intersection of North 50th Street and Martin Luther King Boulevard.  The tornado downed nine 75 foot light poles at a commercial auto auction car lot.  The poles were sheared six feet above ground level and fell atop several parked vehicles.
Tornado destroyed boat shed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm moved out of St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana into extreme south Mississippi. Several short lived tornadoes touched down as it crossed Pearl River, Hancock, and Harrison Counties. Near Nicholson, a tornado touched down near Nicholson, moving through a mobile home park and also passing across the Mississippi Visitors Center on Interstate Highway 59. Damage path was estimated at  approximately four miles, due to lack of ground access in Pearl River drainage area to the west of Nicholson. Preliminary reports from Pearl River County and state officials indicated that 3 single family homes were destroyed and 18 others heavily damaged; and 21 mobile homes were destroyed and 8 others heavily damaged.  Several car windows were blown out when the tornado passed through the Visitors Center. One person was injured in the mobile home park and another person suffered minor injuries in a nearby subdivision when their auto was hit by falling trees and limbs. Large hail was also reported by the Sheriffs Office in McNeil. Two addtional tornado touch-downs were reported in north Hancock County and north Harrison County as the severe thunderstorm moved northeast. In north Hancock County, civil defense reported two homes were damaged along with two mobile homes when a tornado touched down in a rural area. In north Harrison County, a tornado damaged a convenience store along with heavily damaging a couple of mobile homes. The tornado path lengths in Hancock and Harrison Counties were estimated from damage reports.

A severe thunderstorm moved out of St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana into extreme south Mississippi. Several short lived tornadoes touched down as it crossed Pearl River, Hancock, and Harrison Counties. Near Nicholson, a tornado touched down near Nicholson, moving through a mobile home park and also passing across the Mississippi Visitors Center on Interstate Highway 59. Damage path was estimated at  approximately four miles, due to lack of ground access in Pearl River drainage area to the west of Nicholson. Preliminary reports from Pearl River County and state officials indicated that 3 single family homes were destroyed and 18 others heavily damaged; and 21 mobile homes were destroyed and 8 others heavily damaged.  Several car windows were blown out when the tornado passed through the Visitors Center. One person was injured in the mobile home park and another person suffered minor injuries in a nearby subdivision when their auto was hit by falling trees and limbs. Large hail was also reported by the Sheriffs Office in McNeil. Two addtional tornado touch-downs were reported in north Hancock County and north Harrison County as the severe thunderstorm moved northeast. In north Hancock County, civil defense reported two homes were damaged along with two mobile homes when a tornado touched down in a rural area. In north Harrison County, a tornado damaged a convenience store along with heavily damaging a couple of mobile homes. The tornado path lengths in Hancock and Harrison Counties were estimated from damage reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado destroyed a business, damaged two homes, and destroyed billboards.  One person received minor injuries due to broken glass.

F1 tornado skipped across U.S. Highway 84 in the Rocky Ford Road/Troupville Highway area just west of Valdosta.  Two rugged steel radio towers (300 and 500 feet tall) lifted off ground and destroyed two miles west of Interstate 75.  Numerous trees and power poles snapped.   Approximately 35 homes and businesses sustained damage in Valdosta.  Several mobile homes heavily damaged.  One mobile home blown 30 feet onto a vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A waterspout moved ashore causing minimal damage to a convenience store and a few mobile homes.
A Brief tornado occurred with no reported damage.
A brief tornado occurred with no reported damage.

An F2 tornado touched down around 3 miles southwest of Merryville along Highway 389 at 8:25 pm, and moved directly through the center of the town before dissipating 1 mile northeast of Merryville. Around ninety homes and businesses received some kind of damage. Most of the damage occurred when large trees fell on homes. Twelve permanent single family homes and fifteen mobile homes were destroyed. The most devastating damage occurred on Cooper Road, where several mobile homes were either picked up or rolled. People in the mobile homes survived by going to their bathrooms and covering up with blankets. Five minor injuries were reported; they were all treated and released from a local hospital.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: 2 homes severely damaged.  Large barn destroyed.  Numerous trees and power lines down.

OES chased a funnel cloud from just southeast of Alpine, southeastward across extreme eastern Howard County into Hempstead County.  The funnel lowered throughout the chase until it touched down and was classified as a tornado 5.5 miles south of Nashville, AR.  Damage initially consisted of broken and felled trees.  The tornado then moved over cleared pastureland and intensified on CR318 between Hwy 4 and CR 44; totally destroying several chicken coups...leaving the chickens untouched...felling a tree onto a car, and slightly damaging a house.  The tornado then began to weaken and rapidly dissipated.  Skywarn spotters living in the area, the Hempstead County Judge and OES were eyewitnesses to the event.
Several buildings severely damaged.  Numerous trees and power lines down.

Several buildings destroyed and numerous other buildings damaged.  Hundreds of trees down.  A number of cattle killed in barn collapse.  Damage estimate included in entry for Morrison county.  Total path length from 1 NE of Lastup to Onamia was 17 miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak (F0 on the Fujita Scale) tornado briefly touched down in Bucks County between Silverdale and Perkasie.  It crossed Callowhill Road between South Perkasie Road and Pennsylvania State Route 113.  Damage was minimal as it was on the ground for less than half a mile and passed over mainly open fields.  Several homes did lose some shingles,  the top of a well pump was blown from its base and a few trees and limbs were knocked down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported and video taped by Arthur Beatty, a storm spotter for Nacogdoches, TX.  His position was on a bluff just north of Hwy 7 and west of Nacogdoches looking to the southwest as the tornado moved northeast.  This position provided good back lighting making spotting easy.  Damage along the track consisted of shallow rooted trees blown over in a convergent pattern, broken limbs, and damaged or blown over signs.  No injuries or monetary damages of significance were noted.  The tornado developed from a rotating wall cloud which lowered to the ground throughout its entire life span.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summary of events of October 8, 1997:A line of severe thunderstorms developed and moved across western and central Oklahoma during the evening, producing large hail, damaging winds, and 2 tornadoes.  The first tornado was observed southeast of billings in Noble County.  No damage occurred, and the tornado was rated F0.  The second tornado touched down south of Coyle in Logan County, destroying a barn and some outbuildings.  Damage was rated F1.The largest hail (up to the size of golf balls) fell in Oklahoma City in Oklahoma County and in Addington in Jefferson County.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts were estimated to be as high as 80 mph (in Perkins in Payne County).  Structural wind damage was reported west of White Eagle in Kay County, near Coyle in Payne County, and east of Guthrie in Logan County.  Tree damage was reported in Meridian in Logan County, south of Perkins and in Chandler in Lincoln County, in Edmond in Oklahoma County, east of Elgin in Comanche County, and in Marlow in Stephens County.See preceding individual Storm Data entries for further details and additional reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado destroyed a barn and outbuildings.
Two waterspouts moved ashore at Seagrove Beach along Walton County Road 30A and Seacrest Drive.  Eleven homes heavily damaged and one destroyed.

An F1 tornado touched down five miles southeast of Vernon near Greenhead on Highway 279.  Three barns, a pickup truck and a doublewide trailer were destroyed.  Two homes sustained roof damage.  Numerous trees were uprooted.
The Sheriff's Office reported one mobile home destroyed, two others damaged and the roof of a house damaged.
HAM  radio operators reported tornadoes  5 miles south and 4.5 miles northeast of Barnesville. There was no reported damage from the intermittent touchdowns.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying tornado initially touched down in New Smyrna Beach about 1 mile west of U.S. Highway 1 between Enterprise and Wayne Avenues. The tornado moved east northeast at about 50 mph damaging several homes and downing trees and power lines. It lifted just west of Highway 1 after passing Chisholm Elementary School. The tornado then struck New Smyrna Beach High School producing Fujita Scale F1 damage. As the tornado intensified to a strong F3 category, it passed thorough the Venetian VIllas subdivision and the Diamond Head Condominiums. A number of large well built homes were destroyed.  Many of the units in the 10 story Diamond Head Condominiums received major damage as high winds blew out exterior glass walls and blew furniture into the adjoining Indian River Lagoon. The tornado then crossed the Intracoastal Waterway and passed over the barrier island between Robinson Road and East Street where a number of large well built homes were almost completely destroyed. The tornado then moved over the Atlantic Ocean. In all 32 people were injured, six requiring hospitalisation. Thirty one homes were destroyed and 290 were damaged. Damage estimates were near 14 million dollars.

Summary of events of the afternoon and evening of August 17, 1997:Severe thunderstorms moved along and south of the Red River, producing large hail, damaging thunderstorm winds, and two tornadoes in western parts of north Texas.  The tornadoes were observed south of Windthorst in Archer County.  No damage was reported and both were rated at F0.  The largest hail was reported near Harrold in Wilbarger County, where hail reached the size of golf balls.  The most significant wind damage occurred in Clay County, where severe thunderstorm winds caused major damage to a group of houses and barns and then derailed a freight train near Jolly.  Significant wind damage was also reported in the Henrietta area of Clay County and  in Iowa park in Wichita County.See preceding individual Storm Data entries for further details and additional reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F0 tornado touched down briefly about 1/5 miles west of Highway 16.  No damage was reported.
F1 tornado destroyed one home five miles west of Blountstown.  One minor injury reported.
Minor  damage was done to 250 homes in southwest Jackson. Most of the damage was to shingles on roofs. Many trees were blown down. A couple of the trees fell on houses.

A fast moving F0 tornado first touched down along Interstate Highway 95 near S.R. 518. The tornado moved rapidly to the east northeast damaging road signs, snapping limbs off of trees and damaging the housing around an airconditioning system on the roof of a grocery store in Melbourne. The tornado continued east northeast and crossed the Indian River and Banana River lagoons and moved over Satellite Beach where it produced minimal damage to tree limbs.

Very small F0 tornado with damage to small rural structures and fencing.  Path width by witness at 10-15 yards.  Tornado accompanying convective band sweeping southwest to northeast through east-Central San Joaquin Valley.
Landspout tornado observed by National Weather Service personnel while doing cooperative observer equipment maitenance.
waterspout moved on shore layton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An F1 tornado touched down in the Ivanhoe subdivision around 6:45 pm, ripping up trees and moved northeast. As it crossed Highway 69, around five miles south of Woodville, it tore the roof off a large barn at a farm, and destroyed the business offices of a sawmill across the street. Over 100 trees were reported down on the farm. Fortunately, this storm moved across mostly wooded land and farm acreage, causing no injuries.

An F1 tornado touched down near FM 252, around 7 miles southwest of Jasper at 7:30 pm, and moved northeast, ripping down trees and power lines. As it crossed Highway 96 in the Zion Hill area, it picked up a mobile home and rolled it uphill for 100 yards, before it ran into a tree. Two people inside the mobile home escaped with minor injuries by climbing in their bathtub just before the tornado struck. The storm then continued to the northeast and dissipated around 4 miles southeast of Jasper, along US Highway 190 in the Holly Springs area, where it damaged the roof of one home and destroyed a barn.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm which developed along a cold front moving into south central Chaves County produced a small, brief tornado. The tornado formed in an environment of northeast surface winds and moderate southwest winds aloft. This is only the second recorded tornado for December in New Mexico. Previously a tornado was reported December 26, 1966 near Pojoaque in Santa Fe County.

An F3 tornado touched down just east of I-65 in Saraland near Shelton Beach Estates.  The tornado skipped east northeast along the ground before lifting  back into the cloud near U S Highway 43.  Three homes were almost completely gone, three more suffered major damage and about  sixty homes in the middle-class neighbourhood suffered some damage.  Most of the damage was consistent with an F1 or F2 tornado.  No one was injured.  Several people knew they were under a tornado warning and were able to take cover before the storm struck.  Most of the residents said they did not hear the familiar "Freight Train Sound" before the tornado struck.

A mesocyclone intermittently produced a weak tornado as the storm tracked northeast across George county.  The tornado first briefly touched down along River Road  near the Barton community where trees were blown down.  The tornado touched down again near Grain Elevator Road blowing down several century old Live Oak trees.  The oak trees fell around a home which sustained only minor damage.  The tornado touched down again just west of State Road 63 where it destroyed two mobile homes and caused major damage to another.  Trees and some outbuildings were also damaged.  The tornado again briefly touched down along Barton Agricola Road where trees were blown down.   The tornado then touched down in the Howell community on the edge of George county.  Trees  were blown down along County Road 612 where a mobile home was completely destroyed and another damaged.  Six persons in the destroyed mobile home were injured.  Most of the damage from the tornado was in the F0 range with F1 damage occurring with the destruction of the mobile homes in the Barton and Howell communities.  A total of seven people were injured with two admitted to a hospital where they were later released.  The tornado then moved into Mobile county just west of Wilmer.
One house was move off its foundation, the top of a mobile home was taken off,  and several trees were blown down across the road.

An F1 tornado touched down in Northeast Jackson County then tracked northeast through Western Atchison County south of Route  9  to 2 miles northwest of Muscotah.  Spotters then tracked the tornado northward along  Highway 159  to   2 miles south of Horton in Brown County which is 7 miles north of Muscotah.  The tornado was estimated to be  traveling at a speed of 40 to 45 MPH. Numerous power lines were reported blown down and two farm outbuilding were destroyed 2 miles northwest of Muscotah. The path of the tornado was based on the track through Atchson County only.
BRIEF TOUCHDOWN OVER OPEN COUNTRY
COMBINE FLIPPED ONTO IT'S SIDE AND ONE BARN RIPPED FROM IT'S FOUNDATION.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over the Black Hills and surrounding plains and moved northeast into Meade County. The storms strengthened causing widespread wind and hail damage from Central Meade County into Ziebach County. Windows were broken out of homes, schools, and cars. Roofs were ripped off several buildings. Highways 34, 212, and 73 were briefly closed in some areas due to high water and deep hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado reported by law enforcement officer along Highway 34. Path length and width are estimated.

Another supercell thunderstorm brought large hail and a tornado to southeast Otero county.  The storm and accompanying tornado moved out of open country southwest of the Higbee Valley and struck several ranches just north of the Purgatoire River on Road 804.  At about 8:45 p.m. the tornado struck three ranches about 3 miles southwest of Higbee.  Some barns were destroyed, and roofs were ripped off others.  Horse trailers, windmills, feed troughs, hay feeders, water tanks, grain storage bins were destroyed.  Many large cottonwood trees were broken off or uprooted.  The tornado ripped through the northwest side of Higbee, and one horse perished from injuries due to flying debris there.  The tornado then moved northeast through open ranch country for another 5 miles, with the only known damage being two downed power poles.

A brief tornado was reported by a Crowley county sheriffs officer on the outskirts of Crowley.  There was no known damage.  The brief, weak tornado was associated with the line of thunderstorms to the west of several supercell storms.
Brief tornado touchdown left pine trees 15-20 inches in diameter uprooted. A camp suffered structural damage to small building.

During the evening of September 15th a small tornado struck the ranch of Rick and Judy Hoyt near Burns, Oregon. The short lived tornado twisted and snapped a pine tree,  threw large bails of hay,  broke a window and damaged power lines around the homestead.  A witness in nearby Hines, Oregon reported seeing a funnel cloud  around the same time.
Large trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A  police officer reported that a small tornado touched down briefly in open country.

A severe thunderstorm produced a tornado as it moved into St. Tammany Parish. The tornado was first observed by the State Police on Interstate Highway 12 west of  Covington. From data collected on a ground, damage survey by the National Weather Service, the tornado moved on a path slightly north of due east. The tornado moved across the downtown area of Covington and continued east for nearly 2 miles before lifting off the ground.  Most of the damage along path indicated F1 damage, however, several areas near downtown Covington were classified as F2 damage. Parish officials reported 43 injuries were reported with tornado, though most were relatively minor. Six persons required and overnight stay in a hospital, including three pregnant women. Most of the damage to homes was due to large pine trees which had been toppled onto houses. In downtown Covington, a few large buildings lost roofs, had windows blown out, or suffered substantial damage. A large parish building suffered $500,000 damage. Media reports indicated cleanup would cost several million dollars. Just east of the downtown area, several cars were lifted and moved tens of feet by the tornado, and an empty tractor-trailer truck rig was blown over. Nearly 50 cars in a parking lot had their windows blown out by debris or by rapid pressure drop. The same parent thunderstorm spawned another tornado just south of Talisheek damaging a barn and a house. The damage path length at Talisheek was estimated.   American Red Cross reports indicated 69 single family homes were destroyed or had major damage in St. Tammany Parish.  Four public buildings were also heavily damaged.

The same supercell thunderstorm that brought large hail and a brief tornado to eastern Otero county produced a long track tornado through northwestern Bent and central Kiowa counties.  The tornado began about 7 miles west of Las Animas.  Eleven people were in the direct path of the tornado as it hit a ranch house and adjacent outbuildings.  Five men were caught outside, trying to move their vehicles from harm's way.   Four were thrown about by the tornado and received minor injuries.  Six women in the ranch house were unhurt.  The tornado moved northeast and blew a vehicle off Highway 194.  The occupant received minor injuries.  It destroyed a stream level monitor on the other side of the highway, then ripped through a line of trees before moving into barren country.  Eyewitnesses said the tornado remained intact for most of the 35 mile track northeast to just south of Highway 96 in Kiowa county.  Owing to the nearly uninhabited, barren landscape, little if any damage occurred beyond Highway 194 in Bent county.

A severe thunderstorm moved out of St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana into extreme south Mississippi. Several short lived tornadoes touched down as it crossed Pearl River, Hancock, and Harrison Counties. Near Nicholson, a tornado touched down near Nicholson, moving through a mobile home park and also passing across the Mississippi Visitors Center on Interstate Highway 59. Damage path was estimated at  approximately four miles, due to lack of ground access in Pearl River drainage area to the west of Nicholson. Preliminary reports from Pearl River County and state officials indicated that 3 single family homes were destroyed and 18 others heavily damaged; and 21 mobile homes were destroyed and 8 others heavily damaged.  Several car windows were blown out when the tornado passed through the Visitors Center. One person was injured in the mobile home park and another person suffered minor injuries in a nearby subdivision when their auto was hit by falling trees and limbs. Large hail was also reported by the Sheriffs Office in McNeil. Two addtional tornado touch-downs were reported in north Hancock County and north Harrison County as the severe thunderstorm moved northeast. In north Hancock County, civil defense reported two homes were damaged along with two mobile homes when a tornado touched down in a rural area. In north Harrison County, a tornado damaged a convenience store along with heavily damaging a couple of mobile homes. The tornado path lengths in Hancock and Harrison Counties were estimated from damage reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: F0 tornado inflicted structural damage to Woolworths department store on US Highway 90 in Marianna.  Numerous 12" diameter trees snapped.
F1 tornado moved across Houston County Road 85.  Two homes sustained extensive roof damage.  A semitractor trailer was overturned.  Numerous trees and power lines down in Ashford and Gordon.
F1 tornado reported near Rowena.  One home destroyed and a mobile home lifted off its foundation.  Numerous trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down at the northwest edge of the Manhattan Airport and damaged a barn as it travelled along the ground for three hundred yards.  The tornado moved northeast and touched down briefly again in the west to northwest side of Manhattan where it destroyed part of the roof on three homes, knocked down several road signs and downed a few trees and power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moving east through western Bent county merged with a northeast moving supercell thunderstorm just west of Las Animas.  The hail quickly grew from one inch in diameter up to 4.50 inches in diameter.  A tornado and high winds skipped across the landscape for about 8 miles from about 3 miles west northwest of Las Animas through ranch country of north central Bent county.  Windows were broken and roofs were destroyed on houses, outbuilding were damaged and destroyed, and vehicles were damaged and destroyed by both the high winds and hail.
Flag poles at Conroe High School Football Stadium bent over.  As the storm passed just south of the Conroe Airport the ASOS recorded 57 mph winds from the south.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado damaged several sheds and downed several large trees.  The tornado travelled three miles through eastern Jackson County before crossing into western Atchison County at 621 PM CST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early morning tornado damaged two houses nine miles south of Colorado City.  The tornado also destroyed a shed, blew over three gasoline storage tanks, and tore the roof off of a barn.
Trees blown down.

This tornado was probably the most significant in strength and length that occurred this day.  Several homes and mobile homes received major damage.  There was one injury when a young boy was in a mobile home when the tornado picked it up and wrapped it around a tree.  Damage to trees was extensive with many trees being snapped off above the ground.  This storm was surveyed from the air and had continuous tree damage from Midway to Shepherd in San Jacinto County.

Several buildings destroyed and numerous other buildings damaged.  Hundreds of trees down. A number of cattle killed in barn collapse. One man injured when the tornado engulfed his car and threw it into a nearby woods.  A second man critically injured when his garage collapsed.  He died several weeks later.Total path length of tornado from 1 NE of Lastrup to Onamia was 17 miles.
A short-lived tornado touched down near U.S. Highway 17 northeast of Ft. Ogden in rural southwest De Soto county and snapped a few power poles.
A small tornado blew the roof off a church, downed several power lines and uprooted three large trees on County Road 555, two miles north of County Road 630.

A tornado briefly touched down one mile south of Opp near the community of Beulah.  Three homes were hit by the tornado.  One home was completely destroyed and two others suffered major damage.   Five family members in the destroyed home said they huddled in the hallway and were not injured.  They said it sounded like a freight train moved through.  Two large empty chicken houses were also destroyed.   A barn and several outbuildings  also suffered damage.  Trees and power lines were  blown down.  Several vehicles and farm implements also were damaged by the fallen trees.  One cow was killed by the debris.  Another cow was found wandering in the road, but there was no way for the cow to have gotten there unless it was picked up and set on the other side of a fence that was not damaged by the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough aloft spawned funnel clouds and a tornado over coastal areas of central Orange County.  Although no thunder or lightning was detected, convective showers were observed in the area.  The tornado touched down near the Irvine Spectrum Center and travelled about a quarter of a mile  on the ground, ripping away a chain-link fence at a construction site, which landed on 30 cars a few hundred yards away.  Four cars were reportedly picked up and moved a few feet, and wooden beams were tossed about like toothpicks.  No injuries were reported, but ten cars were damaged by flying debris and a shuttle shelter was destroyed.  As the tornado lifted, another funnel developed and lasted for several minutes.

A second tornado touched down in Beauregard Parish. This one, an F1, touched down around 8:55 pm in the Mennonite community south of DeRidder. Fortunately, this storm passed over mostly farmland and wooded acreage. Around five homes were damaged, and two barns were destroyed. The most serious damage occurred on North Mennonite Road, where two barns were destroyed, and the roof was blown off one home. The debris from these buildings was blown across a field for over a quarter of a mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near State Road 699 (Gulf Boulevard) and 6th Avenue, moved northeast and dissipated near the intersection of County Road 590 and Old Coachman Road.  The tornado left thousands of electrical customers without power, knocked down numerous trees, caused several roofs to collapse and shattered windows from Indian Rocks Beach northeast through Largo and primarily in Clearwater.Damage from the tornado totalled $4.5 million dollars.  From Indian Rocks Beach, through Largo to Clearwater, 190 buildings received damage from the tornado.  Four million dollars of the damage occurred to properties in Clearwater, $300,000 in Indian Rocks Beach, and $200,000 in Largo.The tornado caused major damage to 19 homes while another 135 suffered minor damage.  Sixteen apartment buildings incurred major damage while ten others suffered minor damage from the tornadic wind.  Also, eleven businesses and a high school gym in Clearwater suffered minor to moderate damage.

Several F1 tornado touchdowns in southern Miller County.  Felled 24" diameter pines damaged a mobile home on Mayhaw Road.  One home heavily damaged and nearby boat, camper and chicken house destroyed.  Many power lines down countywide.
Tornado skipped Eastward along US-82. Two homes recieved minor damage.
This tornado moved along HWY 105.  Moderate damage to homes, businesses, and a school.
Damage to trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small F0 tornado touched down along Highway165, two miles north of Fenton, and dissipated around two miles south of Elton. Two homes lost shingles from their roofs, and numerous trees and power lines were blown down. After the tornado dissipated, the main thunderstorm produced another tornado in Acadia and Evangeline Parishes.

A small F1 tornado touched down in northwestern Acadia Parish, around two miles southwest of Basile. This storm moved northeast and passed through sections of Basile in Evangeline Parish before dissipating. The most serious damage occurred in Acadia Parish, along Fournerat Road, where several homes received roof and window damage. In Basile, the high school and a rice drier received minor damage when light poles were blown down. Trees and power lines were down for several miles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Landspout destroyed or damaged 21 trailers in the Croatan Mobile Home Park.
Trees down and minor structural damage.
Mainly tree damage from Midway to Shepherd.
WCM confirms brief tornado touchdown...F0
Numerous public sightings of a small tornado moving through East Heritage subdivision near Hiland Park.  Minor roof damage reported.
A brief F0 tornado touchdown south of Alabama Highway 84 near Daleville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air moving across the relatively warm waters of Lake Erie produced a waterspout which moved onshore in the Town of Evans. The weak tornado downed power lines and five large maple trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two F1 tornados reported along Highway 277 near Vernon.  Several homes suffered considerable roof damage.  A  mobile home was damaged between Vernon and Wausau on Highway 79.

An F0 tornado developed as a severe thunderstorm was dissipating in rural, west Merced County just south of Los Banos.  Damage was essentially limited to stored grain/fodder for cattle and some fences.  Tornado was reported by several witnesses with its last point 3 miles farther south than its initial touchdown point.  The path was from the NNW to SSE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The tornado first touched down in the Rowan Community in extreme eastern Bladen County. The Storm then moved across the county line and the tornado touched down again near Penderlea, in Pender County. NWS personnel surveyed the storm damage 5 miles west of Penderlea and estimated the wind speed at around 72 mph. Dr. Joe Medrano (certified meteorologist) surveyed the site of the Bladen Co. tornado and his findings indicated that the damage in the Rowan community was consistant with an F1 tornado.

The tornado first touched down in the Rowan Community in extreme eastern Bladen County. The Storm then moved across the county line and the tornado touched down again near Penderlea, in Pender County. NWS personnel surveyed the storm damage 5 miles west of Penderlea and estimated the wind speed at around 72 mph. Dr. Joe Medrano (certified meteorologist) surveyed the site of the Bladen Co. tornado and his findings indicated that the damage in the Rowan community was consistant with an F1 tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An F1 tornado lifted a roof off a barn four miles west of Malone.  Many large trees toppled and some fences destroyed.
A small F0 tornado observed from Heritage Woods Road to the St. Andrew Marina.  No damage reported.
Brief tornado moving southeast.
Brief tornado moving southeast.

Apparently very small tornado (F0) or gustnado accompanied a line of convection through the east-Central San Joaquin Valley.  Tornado/gustnado path was from SSE to NNW.  Damage confined to minor roof damage and uprooting small trees in a north Clovis suburb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A  tornado touched down but caused no damage since it was in open country.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Photos and eyewitness reports confirmed that a very weak tornado touched down in the Drift Road section of Westport.  A few tree tops were broken off.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The same supercell thunderstorm that brought large hail to the La Junta area, generated a brief tornado in a rural area of northeast Otero county.  It broke off a power pole and caused no other known damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A  tornado touched down briefly near the Jeffery Energy Plant.

A  tornado touched down twice on the northeast corner of town, producing minor damage to five homes but destroyed the garages attached to two of the homes.  A camper-trailer was also damaged and several utility poles were knocked down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The same supercell thunderstorm which spawned a tornado in southeast Otero county in the Higbee Valley dropped a brief, weak tornado west southwest of Las Animas in a ranch land area.  Grass was laid down, but there was no known property or crop damage.  Knowledge of this and other supercell tornadic thunderstorms moving east of La Junta prompted law enforcement to stop an eastbound Amtrak train and evacuate the 300 passengers around 9:00 p.m.  The train was allowed to travel on to Chicago around 11:00 p.m.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep southerly flow of modified tropical air produce two small spin-up tornadoes in the western Virginia piedmont  during the late afternoon.  The first touchdown occurred near Orange.  A witness at the Piedmont Research Center saw a funnel cloud briefly touch down into a field, causing a debris swirl (most likely dirt and grass).  The tornado  lifted as quickly as it touched down, near federal highway 15.  A survey team noted only a swirling effect flattened grass in the field.A stronger twister touched down about an hour later near Radiant.  The twister, witnessed by several onlookers, first moved across a farm field, causing minor damage to a building and an adjacent satellite dish before flipping an empty livestock truck.  The truck, which landed on hay bales, was undamaged.  The storm moved through a wooded area, then moved into a residential area where a dozen trees were uprooted or snapped.  Minor damage was sustained to the houses.  The twister then dissipated.  Estimated winds ranged from 70 to 80 mph.

The same supercell thunderstorm that brought large hail and a brief tornado to eastern Otero county produced a long track tornado through northwestern Bent and central Kiowa counties.  The tornado began about 7 miles west of Las Animas.  Eleven people were in the direct path of the tornado as it hit a ranch house and adjacent outbuildings.  Five men were caught outside, trying to move their vehicles from harm's way.   Four were thrown about by the tornado and received minor injuries.  Six women in the ranch house were unhurt.  The tornado moved northeast and blew a vehicle off Highway 194.  The occupant received minor injuries.  It destroyed a stream level monitor on the other side of the highway, then ripped through a line of trees before moving into barren country.  Eyewitnesses said the tornado remained intact for most of the 35 mile track northeast to just south of Highway 96 in Kiowa county.  Owing to the nearly uninhabited, barren landscape, little if any damage occurred beyond Highway 194 in Bent county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado damaged a large barn and a pole barn.
F1 tornado damaged approximately 12 homes.  Numerous trees and power lines down.  A van was overturned by high winds.  Both occupants suffered minor injuries.
A small F1 tornado destroyed a barn on Alabama Highway 92.  A neighboring house sustained minor damage.  Several trees were uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers developed during the afternoon in southeastern Massachusetts and these went on to produce three waterspouts, at least one confirmed weak tornado (F0) and numerous funnel clouds..  The weak tornado occurred in the Pine Hills section of the town of Plymouth, near Cliff Rock, where a police officer saw tree-top debris being carried upward into the funnel.  The touchdown time was 1:27 PM and was reported to have lasted between 15 and 55 seconds.  The first waterspout occurred just east of the Sagamore Bridge, over Cape Cod Bay, at 1:30 PM.  At 2:15 PM, a second waterspout was sighted one mile east of Gurnet Light to the east of Plymouth.  A third waterspout was reported just west of Bourne, over Buzzards Bay, at 3:20 PM.  Throughout the afternoon,  there were numerous reports of funnel clouds, some of which appeared in newspaper photos and documented via amateur radio operators' videos.  Many of the funnels came as far a half-way down before retreating up into the cloud.  While it is possible that there were other very brief touchdowns of very thin funnels, none were able to be confirmed.  The waterspouts made for dramatic video footage which aired on area television newscasts and on The Weather Channel.  Cloud tops associated with the convection that produced these phenomena were in the low range...from 10,000 to 20,000 feet, except for a few  isolated clouds which grew slightly higher.  There were no reports of damage or injury as a result of these events.

Summary of events of October 8, 1997:A line of severe thunderstorms developed and moved across western and central Oklahoma during the evening, producing large hail, damaging winds, and 2 tornadoes.  The first tornado was observed southeast of billings in Noble County.  No damage occurred, and the tornado was rated F0.  The second tornado touched down south of Coyle in Logan County, destroying a barn and some outbuildings.  Damage was rated F1.The largest hail (up to the size of golf balls) fell in Oklahoma City in Oklahoma County and in Addington in Jefferson County.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts were estimated to be as high as 80 mph (in Perkins in Payne County).  Structural wind damage was reported west of White Eagle in Kay County, near Coyle in Payne County, and east of Guthrie in Logan County.  Tree damage was reported in Meridian in Logan County, south of Perkins and in Chandler in Lincoln County, in Edmond in Oklahoma County, east of Elgin in Comanche County, and in Marlow in Stephens County.See preceding individual Storm Data entries for further details and additional reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was observed by spotters. No damage was reported.

The tornado that moved through the Howell community in Mississippi then moved into Mobile county where the storm blew down several trees and damaged some outbuildings before lifting back into the cloud near U S Highway 98 just west of Wilmer.  As in George county, the tornado was only on the ground for a short period of time.  No injuries were reported in Mobile county.

An F0 tornado touched down about five miles northwest of Greenville along State Road 185.  The tornado began about a mile west of State Road 185 and moved toward 185 then went back into the cloud near State road 185.  The weak tornado skipped along the ground for about one mile and damage was about 150 yards wide along the track.  Most of the damage was to trees.  A metal garage along Highway 185 was the only structure to suffer major damage.  No one was injured.
An F0 tornado touched down very briefly about 3 miles east-northeast of Clinton.  The only damage noted along the path of the tornado was a few trees that were knocked down.
An F0 tornado touched down very briefly near Edgemont.  A couple of downed trees were the only damage noted along the path of the tornado.
National Weather Service employee witnessed a short-lived and weak tornado.
